Disposition: Disposition Process
   
  Demilitarization  
         
  Once the item has been identified to be sold or destroyed which has inherent military applications, the system must be demilitarized to preclude the unauthorized use of military equipment. This does two things: renders potentially dangerous property innocuous and precludes compromise of security requirements. This could be a weapon, weapon system, or a unique military aircraft part (or capability).

Demilitarization is defined as: Act of destroying the offensive or defensive advantages inherent in certain types of military equipment.

Destroying a system is not as simple as it may first appear. There are several factors that must be considered before destroying property:

Environmental Impacts: Military systems have extraordinary amounts of materials which cannot simply be scrapped, burned, or buried. Toxic or corrosive substances must be neutralized prior to disposal. If not, individuals, organizations, services, and the DoD may be liable under federal environmental statutes.		   U.S. Security: The potential impact on U.S. security is immense. Foreign and domestic groups must not be allowed to acquire our military items, so controls must be instituted and maintained. It is vital to safeguard these items. Even if one item were to fall into the hands of our adversaries it would be disastrous. These items can be reversed-engineered, thus providing a military capability that is both cheap and effective. An extensive black market exists for the United States' military equipment because of its superiority and dependability. Allowing our weapons to get into the hands of our enemies slowly erodes our technological advantage. It is up to us as U.S. Air Force members to ensure that items are controlled and the appropriate demilitarization actions are taken. This is done through the assignment of an appropriate DEMIL code which is placed on each item.

   
  For more information on current Demilitarization policy, view the Defense Demilitarization Manual.
